metadata.title: Microsoft Introduction to AI — Part 4 | by Christine Calo | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Conversational AI allows people to communicate with applications, websites and devices everyday in humanlike natural language via voice, text and touch. It offers an engaging and intuitive way of…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: If you would like to know more info behind the course notes and other notes related to tech and product design you can find out more here.
If you would like to know a little background info behind the course notes and other notes related to tech and product design you can find out more here.

all_paragraphs: Conversational AI allows people to communicate with applications, websites and devices everyday in humanlike natural language via voice, text and touch. It offers an engaging and intuitive way of interacting with technology which is revolutionising the way humans relate to machines. We’ve evolved from a world of having to learn and adapt to machines to one where they’re learning how to understand and interact with us.
“For people and machines to work together, they need to be able to interact in a much more natural way, and conversation is our go-to way of exchanging information.”
— Murray Campbell, IBM Distinguished Researcher and architect of DeepBlue

Advances in AI will make the conversational capabilities of computers vastly more sophisticated, paving the way for a sea change in computing. This is Part 4 and the final part of the ‘Microsoft Introduction to Artificial Intelligence’ course notes. Learn about intelligent conversational bots and how to enable natural communication between humans and computers.
(skip the Background info if you have seen Part 1, 2 or 3)

For those who haven’t seen Part 1, 2 or 3 of this series, here is some background info. I’ve always wanted to learn about Artificial Intelligence (AI) although felt a little intimidated by the maths involved and thought maybe some of the concepts would be out of my depth. Fortunately, my curiosity overcame my fear so I’ve started to do a few courses related to AI. I recently completed the Microsoft Introduction to AI course and wrote course notes to help me retain the knowledge that I have learned. I have tried to write these notes in a basic way to make them easy to consume. I’ve recently become an aunt and have bought a few children’s books related to technology and space and really love how the authors and illustrators have managed to simplify complicated topics. So, I’ve been inspired to treat these topics in a similar way by simplifying them to make them a lot more accessible, especially to those who share my initial AI jitters.
*If you would like to know more info behind the course notes and other notes related to tech and product design you can find out more here.*
(skip the Summary if you have seen Part 1, 2 or 3)

The Microsoft Introduction to AI course provides an overview of AI and explores machine learning principles that provide the foundation for AI. From the course you can discover the fundamental techniques that you can use to integrate AI capabilities into your apps. Learn how software can be used to process, analyse and extract meaning from natural language. Find out how software processes images and video to understand the world the way humans do. Learn about how to build intelligent bots that enable conversations between humans and AI systems.

The course takes approximately 1 month to complete so 1 medium article I write contains 1 week's worth of content. This means that it would only take you approximately half an hour to read this article which is 1 week's worth of content. That is a fast way of learning. The course is free without a certificate however, if you’d like a certificate as proof of completion there is a fee. There are labs associated with this course which I won’t include in the notes as I believe the best way to learn is to actually do the labs. However, these notes are useful if you’d like to know about the fundamental theory behind AI and would like to learn it in a way that might be a lot simpler than other resources. I’ve tried to write it in layman terms and have included visuals to help illustrate the ideas. These notes are useful if you don’t have time to do the course, it’s a quick way to skim through the core concepts. Alternatively, if you have done the course like me you can use these notes to retain what you have learned.
Graeme Malcolm — Senior Content Developer at Microsoft Learning Experiences
(skip the Syllabus if you have seen Part 1, 2 or 3)
The course is broken into the four parts which include:
Learn about the fundamentals about AI and machine learning.
Learn how software can be used to process, analyse and extract meaning from natural language.
Learn how software can be used to process images and video to understand the world the way that we do.
Find out how to build intelligent bots that enable conversational communication between humans and AI systems.
The ‘Computer Vision’ part of the course will tackle the following topics:

Think about how often you communicate with other people through instant messaging, social media, email or other online technologies. For many of us that’s our go-to form of contact. Now bots are AI agents that communicate using these types of channels enabling a natural conversational engagement with software services through the same communication channels you use with other humans. In 1950 Alan Turing devised the imitation game which has become known as the Turing test and hypotheses that if a dialog is natural enough you may not know whether you’re conversing with a human or a computer. As AI grows ever more sophisticated, this is becoming a reality.

Microsoft bot framework provides a platform for building and publishing bots. You can use the bot builder SDK or the Azure bot service to create your bot and publish it as a web service. You can make your bot available through one or more channels such as Skype or other popular messaging and social media platforms. The bot connector service handles the message exchange between your bot and the channels through which users engage with it. Each interaction is an activity that can be a message or a visual element such as a card that contains images buttons or input field. When a user starts a dialogue with a bot the activities are routed between the channel and the bot automatically. You can also integrate your bot with cognitive services so it can respond intelligently to user input.

Well let’s take a look at creating a basic bot using the Azure Bot Service. So here we are in the Azure portal and we’re going to create a new web app bot. To do that we just need to add a new resource to your account. We could go and find it in AI & Cognitive Services or just go and simply search for bot. In the search results there is a web app bot and we’re going to create one of these.

So the first thing our bot needs is a name and in this example we’re going to call it “ShoutyBot”. There’s a few other things we’ve got to fill in here. We’re going to create a resource group for it just to manage all the related resources together. We need to choose where we want to deploy that, so we’re just going to pick the data center that’s nearest. We then need to choose the the pricing tier for this bot and there’s a number of pricing options available. In this example we are going to use the free one. Then we need to give it an app name, it’s going to create an Azure web app to support this bot, so we have an app name there for it which just takes the same name as the bot in this case.

Now we’re going to choose the template on which we want to base our bot and there’s a number of different templates that you can use depending on the type of bot you want to build. We’ll simply use the Node.JS basic bot template to generate some simple Node.JS code to create a very simple bot. Next is carrying on setting up these settings.
We’ve chosen the free tier so we won’t be paying anything but we still need to set up a service plan, so we’ll set that up.

Once we’ve done that it’s going to create a storage account to store some of the data that’s used by the bot, it’s automatically generated a name for that so we don’t need to make any changes if we are happy with that. Then it’s going to create some application insights so that we can track the usage of the bot. So that’s all the settings we need to create. We’ll just go ahead and create our bot.

It will go ahead and validate those settings and make sure that we’re ready to go. Then once it’s validated them it’s going to go off and start creating our bot. When deployment has succeeded, we get a little message to say that our bot has been created. If we go and have a look at the resource groups that we have in the Azure subscription, we can see they’ve got a resource group called ShoutyBot.

If we have a look in there we can see all the different resources that are associated with our bot. So they’re all going to be managed together in this resource group and the bot itself is the first one listed here “ShoutyBot”.

So we’ll go and take a look at that and there’s a number of pages here in this that we can use to go and configure and work with our bot. The first thing we’re going to do is go to this Build page and that will let us access an online code editor.

Now we can edit the code for our bot online in the browser or we could work with it locally using in any IDE, like visual studio or something similar. We can download the code as a zip file and synchronise that and even configure something called continuous deployment. So we could have our code in a source control system and synchronise that with the actual bot online. In this example we’re going to use the online code editor so we’ll open up that and that takes us to this online environment. We currently don’t have a readme file — there’s no readme file created for this one; but what we can do is go and start looking at the code for our bot which is in this app.js JavaScript file. There’s some some basic code that’s been put together to work with our bot on the Microsoft Bot Framework and here’s the bit where the bot actually responds to whenever we send in some sort of message.

This is where the code to send the response is and you can see it’s very simple — it’s just one function that just simply says “You said” and it repeats back whatever it was that the user said to the bot.

Now that’s not terribly useful, so we’re going to make a slight modification to it just to prove that we can. This isn’t really going be any more useful but at least we’ll see that it does something. So we’re going to change that to uppercase. So what we’ve now done is written the code so that whenever we say something to the bot, it’s going to shout it back to us in uppercase.

So we’ve done that we can now go and just close this code editor and go back to our bot in the Azure portal. What we’re going to do is test this bot in web chat. We’ll just click Test in Web Chat and when the bot’s ready to test, we can just go and simply type a message. We should get a response from ShoutyBot shouted back in uppercase — hello. So you can see it’s easy enough to create a very simple bot. Just simply create the settings in the Azure portal, then make a minor modification to the code and we get a custom message back.

What we could do now is deploy this bot as a web bot on on a web page for people to use. We can see that if we look in Channels, there is this web chat code here. We can edit this channel here to get the secret keys and the code that we would require to embed that bot in a web page and make it available for people to use. So we very simply put together a bot and deployed that using the Azure Bot Service.

So we’ve seen how to create a simple bot using the Bot framework and we’re ready now to try and use that through various different channels. So here’s our Shoutybot that we created previously and we’ve already had a look at the web chat channel where we can get the code to embed that bot into a web page. There’s a whole bunch of other channels we could use as well such as Cortana, Microsoft Teams, Skype, Bing or even email. So we could use any of these options here to create a way for users to communicate with our bot in the way that they would communicate with other people for example by sending a Skype message or making a call.

So we’ve seen how to build a basic bot and connect it to a channel however to make your bot useful you’re going to need to put some sort of intelligence behind it. You can integrate your bot with cognitive services to understand natural language as text, speech, analyse images or videos. You can even use it to search the web for relevant information, provide specialist information and advice based on a knowledge base. Of course you can combine these capabilities to create sophisticated conversation based AI experiences and enable a natural way for users and software to work together.

We’ve seen how to create a basic bot and how to use the Microsoft bot framework to allow users to connect to that bot over multiple channels, although the bot we’ve created isn’t all that useful. Really what we need is some sort of AI service behind the bot that’s going to provide something of value that users actually want to work with. So we’re going to create a very simple example using a cognitive service called the QnA Service. Let’s take a look at how we can do that.

So here we are in the QnA Maker website and this is the portal where we can use our QnA service to create knowledge bases that we could use in our bot. So we’re going to take a look at creating a new knowledge base and there’s a three-step process for this. The first step is to create an instance of the QnA service in our Microsoft Azure subscription.

So we’ll go ahead and do that and click create QnA service. It will open up another tab and logs us into the Azure portal. Then we can go ahead and create a new Q&A maker service. So we’ll give it a unique name “QnAJokes” because it’s going contain a knowledge base with some fairly terrible jokes, apologies for that. We’re going to choose the subscription we want to create it in and the management pricing tier for for hosting that service. In this example we are just going to choose the free tier for that so that that’s going to allow us to develop it. We’ll have some restrictions but it lets develop it for free. We’ll create a resource group for that just call that QnAJokes and we will also have to choose the search pricing tier. We have a separate pricing tier for when the knowledge base is searched and again we’ll just choose the free tier for that because that’ll do it for developing it. We’ll store it in the West US data center and then we need to create our a web app for this — an Azure app for that for our QnAJokes. We’ll have some app insights so that we can analyse what’s going on with this service and we’ll store those in a central location. So we’ll go ahead and click create and it’ll validate those settings. Then it will go off and provision our QnA Maker service and the web app to host it.

Then when our QnA service has been deployed we can go back to my QnA Maker here. We’re just going to refresh the page so that we get all the information about the QnA Maker that we actually have deployed and it’s going to list the the QnA services that we have available here. So step two is connecting our knowledge base that we’re about to create to the QnA service we’ve just deployed. So we’re going to use our Microsoft Azure directory ID, we’re going to specify the subscription in which we created the service. So we’re creating a new knowledge base that it’s going to service that QnA service.
Then we need to give this knowledge base a name so we just call this ‘Jokebook’.

Now we’re ready to go and populate our knowledge base and if we had an existing FAQ site on our website or if we had a file with FAQs we could go ahead and use those to populate it. Or we could go ahead and just create our knowledge base manually, which is what we’re going to do for this example.

So we’ll say create your KB, we’re ready to go and start creating the questions and answers that we want to have in our knowledge base. Now initially there’s nothing in it so we’re going to go and add a QnA pair. Our question that we’re going to ask is “why did the chicken cross the road” and the answer that goes with that is “to get to the other side”. So we got our our response there and we’ll go ahead and add another QnA pair. So we could have a question like “what’s red and invisible” and the answer to that one is “no tomatoes”. Then finally we’re going to add something here so that when somebody first interacts with the the knowledge base they’re going to say “hello” and the response that is going to be “hello”. It’s not really a question answer it’s just a way of interacting and getting an appropriate response. So we’ve got those values added in there, we’ll go ahead and save and train the knowledge base.

So after it’s been trained we can go ahead and test it. We just simply type in a message “hello” and get back the appropriate response “hello”. “Why did the chicken cross the road” and I get back the appropriate response“ ”to get to the other side”. So my knowledge base is working. I’m getting back the appropriate responses.
That all seems reasonable so we’re ready to go and publish this rather simple knowledge base so that we could use it in a bot or an application. So I’ll go ahead and click publish.

To publish it it’s going to move the QnAs from the test index into a production index so that we can actually access it from our bot that we’re going to create. So we’ll go ahead and publish. That goes and deploys our knowledge base into my QnA maker web service. We can actually see a sample request that we would use to go and connect to that and use it. It’s got various bits of information, various keys in this URL that we’re going to need when we try and connect a bot that we’re going to build later on to the service.

Well I’ve created a QnA knowledge base and we can use it as the back end for a bot. So now we just need to go ahead and create that bot. Well here we are in the Azure portal ready to create our bot. So we’ll just go ahead and add a new web app bot.

When we create our bot we have to give it a name, so we’re going to call it ‘BadJokes’. We’ll put it into the appropriate subscription that we want to use and we will put it into our existing resource group that we created for our QnA service earlier on. So we’ll put on the West US. We’ll choose the appropriate pricing tier for that and then we need an app name. We’re going to use the appropriate template, we’re going to use a template that’s going to let us use the QnA maker.

We’ll stick with C# this time just for a change but what we’ll do is go down and choose the question-and-answer template. It’s going to create the app service plan in the West US and it will create some storage for that bot as well and some apps insights. So we’ll go ahead and and choose create and now we’re going to validate those settings.

It’s going to go off and deploy that new bot, then when the bot has been deployed, we are ready to go and look at that resource. We’ll have to make a few changes before we are ready to use this because we have to connect it to our QnA service. So to do that we’re going to take a look at the application settings for this app service and just load those. If we scroll down a little bit we can see a number of different application settings that we need to use and that are some that are specific to working with the QnA service. We need a QnA authentication key, we need an endpoint host name and we need a knowledge base ID.
Now all of that information is available to us in the QnA knowledge base that we deployed.

So those are the three settings we need to connect our bot to our QnA knowledge base. So we’ll go ahead and save those settings and that’s gone ahead and updated those app settings for us. So we’re now ready to go and test our bot. We can just go and test that in the web chat interface.

Up it comes and we’re ready to start so we can start off just by being polite and saying hello and we get back my response from BadJokes hello. “Why did the chicken cross the road” and we get the proper response “to the other side”. So we’ve now created a bot and we’ve connected that to our QnA knowledge base. We can then deploy that bot through any of the regular channels the bots can be connected to through and it will use that knowledge base to answer the questions that users submit to it.

Personal assistants like Cortana are an increasingly popular way for people to keep track of information and automate tasks and all that kind of thing. These AI powered assistants can learn about the things that we care about and they can help simplify our daily lives. Now you can connect a bot that you’ve published with the bot framework to Cortana as a skill. That enables users to interact with your bot through the Cortana interface.

So here’s the bot we created earlier that’s connected to our Q&A service and what we want to do to use that in Cortana. So if we have a look at the channels for this bot we can see it’s connected to web chat and that’s running just now but we can go ahead and add it to the Cortana channel.

So if we go ahead and configure that and set ourselves up with an organisation and here we just going to simply register this bot with an organisation. So we’ll go ahead and register. When the bot is registered we can see there that we’ve got Cortana listed in that list of channels. If we now go and have a look in our store portal and look in botlets you can see there’s the BadJokes bot.

So that’s now been registered as part of this organisation, we can see all sorts of information here about that as a Cortana skill. So what we want to do is go in and have a look at the Publish setting here. Some of the things we can do are give it a name, so badjokes is the name of the skill and give an invocation name — in other words the the phrase we’re going to use to tell Cortana that this is the service we want to interact with.

We will go ahead and just publish that out ready to use. Now what that means is if we’re just using our computer as normal and we go to Cortana, we can now say things like “Ask bad jokes why the chicken crossed the road”. Cortana has a think about that and then it recognises that we’re trying to connect to this skill that’s called badjokes.

In order for it to connect we need to give it some permission, so we’ll say yes share my information with that skill. This only happens the first time and we get the right response “To get to the other side”. We could then ask a different question of bad jokes, “What’s red and invisible?” and we get our response “No tomatoes”. So we’ve been able to take a bot that we’ve created and we’ve connected it to the Q&A service so we’ve got a knowledge base of questions and answers. Then we’re able to use Cortana as a channel to interact with that and to get information from that interactively by typing in questions or even by speaking.

Thanks for reading this article Part 4, the last part of the Microsoft Introduction to Artificial Intelligence course. If you found this helpful then check out all 4 parts on my Medium account or in Towards Data Science. If you had some trouble with some of the concepts in this article (don’t worry it took me awhile for the information to sink in) and you need a bit more info, then enrol for free in the Microsoft Introduction to AI course. It’s helpful to watch the course videos alongside with these notes.
*If you would like to know a little background info behind the course notes and other notes related to tech and product design you can find out more here.*

Hi, I’m Christine :) I’m a product designer who’s been in the digital field for quite some time and have worked at many different companies; from large companies (as large as 84,000 employees), to mid size and to very small startups still making a name for themselves. Despite having a lot of experience I’m a product designer who has a fear of suffering from the dunning-kruger effect and so I’m continuously trying to educate myself and I’m always searching for more light. I believe to be a great designer you need to constantly hone your skills especially if you are working in the digital space which is constantly in motion.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Striving to Create Tech Products that People Love — Snr Product Designer | Digital Art Director | Writer of Tech
